Docs.summary: Represents the geometry of a circle or ellipse.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Use the EllipseGeometry class with a <xref:System.Windows.Shapes.Path> element or a <xref:System.Windows.Media.GeometryDrawing> to draw an ellipse, or with the <xref:System.Windows.UIElement.Clip%2A> property of a <xref:System.Windows.UIElement> to define an elliptical clip region. The EllipseGeometry class also has many other uses. For more information about EllipseGeometry, see [Geometry Overview](../Topic/Geometry%20Overview.md).
## EllipseGeometry Compared to Ellipse The <xref:System.Windows.Shapes.Ellipse> class has a <xref:System.Windows.Shapes.Shape.Fill%2A>, <xref:System.Windows.Shapes.Shape.Stroke%2A>, and other rendering properties that EllipseGeometry lacks. The <xref:System.Windows.Shapes.Ellipse> class is a <xref:System.Windows.FrameworkElement> and therefore participates in the layout system; it can be used as the content of any element that supports <xref:System.Windows.UIElement> children.
The EllipseGeometry class, on the other hand, simply defines the geometry of an ellipse, and cannot render itself. Because of its simplicity, it has a wider range of uses.
## Freezable Features An EllipseGeometry is a type of <xref:System.Windows.Freezable> object and therefore can be frozen to improve performance. For information about <xref:System.Windows.Freezable> features, such as freezing and cloning, see [Freezable Objects Overview](../Topic/Freezable%20Objects%20Overview.md).

Docs.param: The maximum bounds on the distance between points in the polygonal approximation of the geometry. Smaller values produce more accurate results but cause slower execution. If is less than .000001, .000001 is used instead.

One of the enumeration values, <see cref="T:System.Windows.Media.ToleranceType"> or <see cref="T:System.Windows.Media.ToleranceType">, that specifies whether the tolerance factor is an absolute value or relative to the area of this geometry.
Docs.returns: The area of the filled region of this ellipse.

remarks.format: ## Remarks Some <xref:System.Windows.Media.Geometry> methods (such as GetArea) produce or use a polygonal approximation of the geometry. The tolerance factor specifies the maximum distance between points in this polygonal approximation. Smaller tolerance values produce better approximations, but they require more processing than an approximation with a large tolerance factor.
